Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Multi-physics of Active Systems and Structures II

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
This three year renewal of the Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site program will enhance the educational experience of undergraduate engineering students by actively engaging them in advanced research activities within the Florida A&M University (FAMU)-Florida State University (FSU) College of Engineering (CoE). The program will be a collective effort from a diverse group of engineering faculty engaging topics such as micro air vehicles, multi-modal robots, active flow control, sensors and actuators, and smart materials. The multidisciplinary nature of these projects will engage students in learning cross-cutting technologies through their specific research and group activities. The REU site program has at its overarching goal to motivate more U.S. students, in particular underrepresented minorities and women, to pursue advanced engineering degrees or enter research-oriented careers.

Over a three year period, this REU Site program will engage undergraduate students in a 10-week intensive, summer research experience focused on the common theme of "Multi-physics of Active Systems and Structures II (MASS-II)" which covers interdisciplinary topics such as Micro Air Vehicles (MAV), active flow control, multi-modal robotic systems, smart materials, sensors, and actuators, and autonomous control. The students will work on individualized projects and participate in group activities such as seminars, lab/industry tours, outreach and a group design project.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SITE-Res Exp for Ugrd Site

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project has successfully recruited undergraduate engineering students for an educational and professional enhancement program involving them in advanced research activities and group design experience coordinated by faculty members of the FAMU-FSU College of Engineering (CoE). The overarching goal of the project is to motivate more US students to pursue advanced engineering degrees or enter research-oriented careers.  We leveraged on valuable experience learned from the previous REU programs by recruiting qualified US students, especially under-represented minorities, to participate in our renovated activities and prepared them for advanced degrees and professional careers.  

Intellectual merits: The site has engaged a diverse group of engineering faculty focusing on research topics such as micro air vehicles, multi-modal robots, active flow control, sensors and actuators, smart materials, high speed flow, additive manufacturing, etc.. The multidisciplinary nature of these projects facilitate students’ self-learning capability through their specific research and group activities. We have also involved all participants in activities promoting self-reflection for them to focus on their experiences leading to a deeper learning.

Broader Impacts: The CoE, while combining the strengths of an HBCU in FAMU and a major research university in FSU, has many faculty members with established track records in both scholarly activities and recruitment and education of minority and female engineering students.  Thus, the REU site has worked effectively to increase the number of engineering students, in particular under-represented minorities and women, who will pursue advanced degrees. Working with two NSF HBCU programs, HBCU-RISE and HBCU-CREST, we have established a sustained recruitment pipeline and collaborations with key HBCU schools to further enhance our capability in training and producing African American graduate students, especially at the PhD-level.   

We recruited 43 students during the span of four summers while engaging these students on individualized projects and group activities such as seminars, lab/industry tours, outreach, and self-reflection sessions.  Working with colleagues from the College of Education, we have assessed the effectiveness of the program by systematically conducting surveys, interviews, and project reviews. 

A very high percentage of REU alumni have decided to pursue advanced degrees and many of them entered doctoral programs. In addition, the program has provided valuable mentorship experience for some of our graduate students and postdoc Fellows. Overall, we have recruited 61% under-represented minorities into the program.  Among them, 32% were African American, 11% Hispanic American, and 30% females. These numbers are higher than the general demographic distribution percentages of these URM groups in mechanical engineering, which are 4%, 9%, and 13.5%, respectively according to ASEE 2017 atabase.

In general, most REU alumni have been very successful in pursuing their careers after graduation. Among those we successfully tracked and already graduated, a total of 10 students, or 30%, have chosen to enter the workforce hired by engineering companies such as Northrup Grumman, Boeing, etc. A total of 18 students entered various graduate programs including 8 who pursued their PhD degrees in various schools.  The other 4 students are pursuing M.S. degrees and one has recently graduated and is working in industry.  Overall, we consider that the program has been successful in guiding students into graduate programs (55%) and some have entered the doctoral program (24%).
